column2: Explore Luxembourg Income Study data on inequality.

column10: Adjust for cost sharing within households (equivalized income) Checkbox
column14: subtitle

The [Gini coefficient](#dod:gini) measures inequality on a scale from 0 to 1. Higher values indicate higher inequality. Inequality is measured here in terms of income after taxes and benefits. Income has been [equivalized](#dod:equivalization) – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The [Gini coefficient](#dod:gini) measures inequality on a scale from 0 to 1. Higher values indicate higher inequality. Inequality is measured here in terms of income before taxes and benefits. Income has been [equivalized](#dod:equivalization) – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.
The [Gini coefficient](#dod:gini) measures inequality on a scale from 0 to 1. Higher values indicate higher inequality.

column14: The Palma ratio is a measure of inequality that divides the share received by the richest 10% by the share of the poorest 40%. Higher values indicate higher inequality. Inequality is measured here in terms of income after taxes and benefits. Income has been [equivalized](#dod:equivalization) – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.

The Palma ratio is a measure of inequality that divides the share received by the richest 10% by the share of the poorest 40%. Higher values indicate higher inequality. Inequality is measured here in terms of income before taxes and benefits. Income has been [equivalized](#dod:equivalization) – adjusted to account for the fact that people in the same household can share costs like rent and heating.
The Palma ratio is a measure of inequality that divides the share received by the richest 10% by the share of the poorest 40%. Higher values indicate higher inequality.

The share of the population with income below 50% of the median. Relative poverty reflects the extent of inequality within the bottom of the distribution.
